title: Tuesday, 27th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there -- welcome to Markets Live

PM11:01am

Suppose we need to in on the various bits of tech-related news

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

That's John Shepherd Barron, inventor of the ATM

PM11:02am

The ATM is 50 years old today

PM11:03am

Spin forward to the cutting tech of today...

11:03 am
PM11:03am

https://twitter.com/alexhern/status/879619148640333825

PM11:04am

Ocado's self-driving thing -- it's actually a golf cart with the steering wheel locked

PM11:04am

And then on to the tech backlash...

11:04 am
PM11:04am

In Brussels

PM11:04am

http://europa.eu/r..._IP-17-1784_en.htm

PM11:05am

The European Commission has fined Google €2.42 billion for breaching EU antitrust rules. Google has abused its market dominance as a search engine by giving an illegal advantage to another Google product, its comparison shopping service.

The company must now end the conduct within 90 days or face penalty payments of up to 5% of the average daily worldwide turnover of Alphabet, Google's parent company.
Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, in charge of competition policy, said: "Google has come up with many innovative products and services that have made a difference to our lives. That's a good thing. But Google's strategy for its comparison shopping service wasn't just about attracting customers by making its product better than those of its rivals. Instead, Google abused its market dominance as a search engine by promoting its own comparison shopping service in its search results, and demoting those of competitors.
What Google has done is illegal under EU antitrust rules. It denied other companies the chance to compete on the merits and to innovate. And most importantly, it denied European consumers a genuine choice of services and the full benefits of innovation."

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Cripes!

PM11:05am

That's an eye-catching fine, for sure

BE11:05am

€2.42bn! It's enough to buy two parliamentary majorities!

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Any thoughts on how this plays out, Bryce?

PM11:06am

(The news has only just broken...)

BE11:06am

I've no idea really. I don't know how this works procedurally.

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Remember the US government generally went nuts over the Apple tax thing

BE11:07am

What we can note is that this is one of three cases currently under examination by the EC.

PM11:07am

Will they do the same for Google

11:07 am
BE11:07am

EC also looking at anti-competitiveness for AdSense and Android.

PM11:07am

Or will the penny drop that what constitutes anti-trust behaviour in the EU is probably bad for US consumers as well...?

BE11:08am

Well ......... AdSense and Android, unlike Google Shopping, are services people actually use.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

hmm

BE11:09am

It also throws a new light on the cash Google (or Alphabet, but let's just call it Google) spends lobbying in Brussels. Which is a big heap of money.

PM11:09am

Indeed

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Let me grab an old Cowen note to spell out what's at risk here.

PM11:10am

Facebook must be readying another Help All the Africans PR stunt as we type

BE11:10am

1. SHOPPING GOES FIRST. The EC is conducting multiple antitrust investigations of Google. The two main ones are search bias in online shopping, and Android dominance. We believe the EC's initial focus is potential harm to this party shopping services from Google's more prominent placement of its own paid shopping product in search results.
2. RE-ORG OF SHOPPING RESULTS. As we first wrote in February, we believe the EC is likely to rule that Google has violated EC competition law by favoring its paid shopping ads over organic shopping results. We think the EC will require Google to reorganize how it presents shopping results

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Yep, rejig the listing and also pay 2.4bn smackers. That's how it's played out.

BE11:11am

3. OTHER VERTICALS LIKELY TO FOLLOW -- GOOD FOR OTAS AND YELP. Importantly, we also believe the EC will use the shopping ruling as a first step toward un-biasing other verticals. We believe travel (OTAs) and local search (Yelp) are likely the next verticals the EC will pursue. Our colleague Kevin Kopelman has written that regulating Google power in these areas would be most clearly positive for Yelp, Trivago and TripAdvisor, and a net benefit for Priceline and Expedia as well.

BE11:12am

4. ANDROID IN THE PIPELINE. The other major piece of the EC's antitrust investigation is Android dominance. The EC's Statement of Objections last year indicated a desire for handset makers to have more freedom to preload whichever apps they want and to reduce Google's control over the Android ecosystem. As we wrote last month, we believe Google's settlement with the Russian regulator over Android suggests Google believes the EC will issue a negative ruling on Android as well. And given the much larger and more lucrative EC market, we believe any settlement would require Google to give up more than in the Russia settlement. The concern for Google is potentially losing some degree of mobile clickshare if major internet companies like Facebook and Amazon used new EC-granted rights for handset arrangements that provided greater visibility and interoperability on devices. If Google doesn't settle, we think an EC ruling is likely in Q4 2017.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

We're still without an FTC chair in the US, right?

BE11:13am

There's an argument that an aggressive EU will get some kind of pushback from the Trumpians.

BE11:13am

As in, these damn foreigners attacking our Great American Champions.

11:14 am

And part of that is the argument that US lawmakers get first kick at Google.

PM11:15am

BE11:15am

The EU etc need to join the queue and await the US courts to rule. Genuinely, I've heard this as an argument.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

But let's move on. There's plenty of Google elsewhere, everywhere, always.

11:21 am

PM11:22am

Northgate’s full year results are worse than expected, with underlying PBT of £75.0m vs. £80.1m forecast. This was primarily impacted by a weaker H2 in the UK division, with a reduction in vehicles on hire. Management says that the UK business saw a loss in market share, with the market said to be growing 6% in the period. A full appraisal has been undertaken and several corrective actions have been implemented, including a number of senior executive changes (MD, Sales Director and Marketing Director). However, we note that these roles last changed c.18 months ago. Spain and Ireland had a positive performance in the period. The Group has announced a strategic update which seeks to revive growth in the UK business, but it is difficult to gauge when the benefits of this will come through. Given the disappointment in the UK we expect to reduce our FY’18 and ’19 PBT forecasts, expecting PBT in FY’18 to be around £75m (flat year on year and 8% below our previous forecast). We will review our recommendation and forecasts after the analyst meeting this morning.

BE11:22am

I forget whether white van demand is a lead or a lagging indicator.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

PM11:23am

I'm still surprised by how this 'weak UK' type news comes as bolt-from-the-blue amongst second line stocks

PM11:23am

11:23 am

Leadership, marketing, sales and process inflexibility are some reasons identified as challenging the UK - the disappointment here is that many of these have been identified and addressed before and more new leadership appointments in the UK will take time to bed in. This said, there are now 4,100 vehicles on the new fixed
term contracts providing confidence there is a market here to pursue and the new CEO has completed an initial strategic review (full details in October).

11:26 am

So, I think it was already a stabilisation or a turnaround story. And now it's a stabilisation or a turnaround story from a rather weaker starting point.

11:28 am

I mean sure, the football season ended a month ago but it takes analysts a while to check the results.

BE11:28am

And when they do they check them all at once, on a Friday afternoon.

BE11:28am

And then they step current-year forecasts back by about 8%, ahead of the interims due August.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

So ........... Stifel, and Numis, and Citi, and now Investec.

BE11:29am

We see further headwinds for William Hill with tough comparables given the Euros in 2016, very poor GWMs in all four divisions in the last 2 months of H117E, a credit betting ban in Australia (we estimate a c.17.5% loss of Australian revenue from March 2018), a change in revenue mix in Australia (lower future GWMs) and higher central costs. The Triennial Review poses further risk to Retail revenue while the CMA review raises the risk of fines and lower customer acquisition/monitored bonusing. We set our TP at 245p (prev. 279p) and downgrade to SELL from Hold.

BE11:29am

FY17/FY18E EPS downgraded by 8.1%/5.0: We lower FY17E EPS to reflect weaker GWMs YTD, higher central costs and changes to the revenue mix (more racing and less sports) which we expect to lead to lower future GWMs. For FY18E, we reduce EPS for these reasons as well as an Australian ban on credit betting (assumed from 1 March 2018 onwards).

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Last 2 months of H117: WMH last updated the market on 9th May, when it reported net revenue growth of 9%. We expect GWMs to be significantly lower across all 4 divisions for the remaining 2 months of H117E given punter-friendly sports results. We estimate Retail, Online, Australian and US gross win margins of 16.5%, 5.8%, 7.6% and 5.6% respectively for the remaining 2 months of H117E. This results in H117E GWMs for Retail, Online, Australia and the US of 17.5% (H116: 19%), 6.9% (H116: 7.3%), 8% (H116: 9.9%) and 6% (H116: 5.7%) respectively. We now forecast FY17E EBIT of £258.7m.

BE11:29am

Aussie credit betting and lower future GWMs: We downgrade FY18E Australian revenue by 8.3% and EBIT by 10.9% (assuming 10 months of the credit betting ban). We now assume a GWM between 9% and 10% (down from 10%-11%) given changes in revenue mix (more racing, less sport and less in-play).
Valuation: We lower our target price to 245p to reflect higher central costs, the credit betting ban in Australia and greater risk surrounding both the CMA review and Triennial Review given the outcome of the recent UK election. We value the Group at 8.0x FY17E adj. EV/EBITDA. The shares trade at 8.5x FY17E EV/EBITDA.

BE11:30am

Now, should we expect a similar magnitude of gross win margin downgrades among the peer group? Because I haven't seen any yet.

BE11:34am

Interestingly, Berenberg managed to get the following comment through compliance.

BE11:34am

● As usual, positives and negatives from this deal. As always when Teddy Sagi places a stake in Playtech there are reasons to cheer and reasons to be worried. Starting with the former, Sagi’s presence in the shareholding of the company is usually seen as increasing corporate governance risks. Moreover, while we have no factual elements to prove it, we believe that
Sagi’s substantial shareholding in Playtech may have been one of the reasons for the company struggling to get hold of some financial trading businesses (Ava Trade and,
importantly, Plus 500 in 2015). The reduction of Sagi’s stake could re-launch Playtech’s appetite for financial trading businesses, Plus 500 on top – which may help the scale of the
business but also add to earnings volatility. On the negative side, this new, quite sudden ABB is likely to drive the shares down significantly tomorrow, and with the stock having hit an
all-time high of £10/share in the past few days, in our view it is unlikely to recover in the short term.

11:34 am

● We expect the stock will take time to recover. While we remain fundamentally buyers of Playtech with a price target of £12.5/share, we acknowledge that it may take time for the
shares to recover (all previous placements did take place at less than £9/share). Still, current trading multiples of 11x P/E, 8.5x EV/EBITA and a hefty 4% dividend yield on 2018E
numbers support a long-term buy on the shares.

● We use a DCF with 10% WACC and 2% perpetual growth.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

A bidder in a new approach would obviously have to develop a strategy to prevent another failure. We do not believe it was so much about the price; rather it appeared to be the acceptance ratio and it is still unclear what parties decided not to tender. For a takeover we believe a predator wants control via domination and profit and loss transfer agreement, which requires a 75% vote of attending capital at the AGM. The question is if one is willing and able to stretch the acceptance ratio, e.g. assuming 65% (or less) tendered shares will still give you 75% at the AGM, given later tendering of index funds and some capital not attending. While the risk of a deal has now significantly increased, it still remains entirely possible. Overall we believe the shortage of assets is still more pronounced than the availability of funds that are looking for investment opportunities.

BE11:44am

The stock was EUR50 on 10 February before a first bid was announced. Given the narrow margin by which the deal failed we now ascribe a 50%
probability to a successful deal in a potential second approach. Equally weighting EUR50 and the former EUR66 bid level yields our new target
price of EUR58 (EUR62.5 before). At this level, Stada would trade at 11.3x EV/adj. EBITDA and 18x adj. P/E, both 2017E. Based on yesterday’s closing price we reiterate our Reduce rating

BE11:44am

And Jefferies.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

We are perplexed as to why investors didn’t take the deal: We had viewed a €66 deal as a great deal to shareholders when it was announced and recommended investors take the offer. This represented a c.48.9% premium to STADA's unaffected share price. We had previously valued a best case offer at €65 so are therefore very surprised that the deal hasn’t won enough shareholder support. We did not anticipate an interloper, or counter-bid, and believe it will take time for fundamentals to command the same kind of premium.

BE11:44am

Our fundamental value is €48 per share: Our TP was last updated prior to the most recent deal speculation and subsequent offer, and also the recent guidance raise. We expect the shares to come under significant pressure, but perhaps not to our fundamental TP level, as we anticipate some might be hoping a deal can be salvaged, and others may be more optimistic about the next 2 years on fundamental guidance vs. our expectations

PM11:45am

(BornCynic -- we certainly need a plan)

11:44 am
BE11:45am

(@alewis2005: did I say four?!?!? Jees! I meant five! I'm a balloon, apologies.)

BE11:45am

And Bankhaus Lampe, who have a nice turn in Google Translate blank verse.

BE11:45am

We would argue that too many shareholders held back shares not because they believed in a higher intrinsic value of Stada as an independent entity but because they hoped for a better price once the first hurdle was taken.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

(@MCStriker: yep, whitewash. That's what I said no?)

BE11:46am

FRUITLESS SPECULATION OF BETTERMENT
• There seemed to be consensus on the offer being attractive and well negotiated. We therefore believe that the outcome is probably due to speculation of betterment, causing investors to hold back shares, rather than the belief that Stada would be better off on its own.

• The rationale behind the strategy to hold the shares may have been reasonable as Bain/Cinven is likely to have targeted a 75% majority in order to implement a cash transfer agreement. However, the needle’s eye was slightly too narrow eventually.

• As hope springs eternal, pricing of Stada shares may still reflect the theoretical chance of an alternative bid from Adven/Permira – if potentially at a moderate discount – or a second attempt by Bain/Cinven with approval provided by Bafin and Stada’s management.

PM11:47am

FRUITLESS SPECULATION OF BETTERMENT -- wonderful

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Isn't it.

BE11:47am

BALANCING FUNDAMENTALS AND HOPE FOR SECOND ATTEMPT
• Unsurprisingly, Stada’s management has reiterated its guidance and feels strong enough to proceed independently. For 2017, the company targets group sales adjusted for currency and portfolio effects of € 2.28-2.35 bn, adj. EBITDA of € 430-450 m and adjusted net income of € 195-205 m.

• Based on our model (which is closer to the lower end of the guidance range), fundamentals suggest a fair value in the mid fifties (€).

• We sense that hope for another attempt to take over Stada is still lingering on and may help mitigate the initial disappointment.

• Stada’s share price is likely to be volatile in the coming days and weeks, which could offer opportunities once the dust has settled

BE11:47am

"The needle’s eye was slightly too narrow eventually."

11:54 am

I'm not sure. I need a catchup with the Debenhams story, but now it's drifting into the smallcaps it seems a lot of work for very little.

BE11:55am

Anyway, here's Citi to summarise.

BE11:56am

Debenhams expects to deliver FY17 PBT within the current range of market expectations but continued volatility could mean an outcome towards the lower end of the current consensus PBT range (£95m-£105m). A combination of more volatile top line trends, gross margin guidance unchanged and lower cost growth is likely to result in consensus FY17 PBT reducing by c1-2%

11:56 am
BE11:57am

(@FatDaz: the Westfield W12 one seems to have about six food concessions in it. Which feels unnecessary in a shopping centre that already has several dozen food concessions in it.)

BE11:57am

3QQ group ccy LFL -2.4%, slightly below forecast (Citi LFL -2.0%) — For the 15-week period ended 17 June, group LFL sales were -2.4% (constant currency) reflecting a more volatile clothing environment in the UK, particularly through May partly offset by continuing growth in Beauty, Accessories and Food & Drink. However full price growth remains solid (+1.7% over the period) with a good control of seasonal stock. Performance in International has seen an improvement in constant currency growth with positive growth in Denmark offset by weaker trading in the Middle East and Republic of Ireland.

BE11:57am

Online sales growth +7.9% yoy – Online sales were +7.9% yoy versus the c.+14.6% growth seen through 1H. Trends in mobile remain positive with +47% growth yoy and improved conversion rates.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

As we've observed before: the internet's a big place, so why would you use it to shop at Debenhams?

BE11:58am

School uniforms possibly. Can't see much else as an angle.

BE11:59am

 FY17 guidance — Gross margin guidance is unchanged from -25bp (Citi -30bp). Cost growth for FY17 is now expected to be at the lower end of the +3-4% range (Citi +2.3%). Other guidance unchanged.
 Progressing with new strategy – Debenhams is making progress in its new Debenhams Redesigned strategy particularly on the ‘Fix the Basics’ plan with ongoing reduction in stock options, completion of the single warehouse management system and improvements in replenishment times.
 Implications — FY17 consensus PBT likely to reduce modestly — On the back of the slightly volatile clothing revenue trends but maintained gross margin and better cost control guidance we expect consensus FY17 PBT forecasts to reduce modestly by c1-2%. We have an August 2017 PBT forecast of £98.8m (EPS 6.4p, - 14.6% yoy). This assumes Group LFL sales -0.4%, gross margins -30bp and opex growth of +2.3% yoy.
 Neutral — Our price target is based on a 8.0x target EV/EBIT multiple for FY17e. This equates to a c.8.5x PE multiple and c.6 % yield.

11:59 am

London, England and San Francisco, CA - 27 June 2017 - RhythmOne plc (LSE AIM: RTHM, "Company" or "1R"), a digital advertising technology company that connects audiences with brands through content across devices, today announces that it has acquired certain assets of RadiumOne, Inc. (the "Acquisition"), a leading data-driven marketing platform. The transaction was signed and closed after market hours on 26 June 2017.

12:01 pm

London, England and San Francisco, CA. - 27 June, 2017 - RhythmOne plc ("RhythmOne", "1R" or the "Company"; LSE AIM: RTHM), is pleased to announce that Mr. Edward ("Ted") Hastings, President of RhythmOne will succeed Mr. Subhransu "Brian" Mukherjee as Chief Executive Officer of the Company, effective 19 July 2017.

PM12:02pm

This transition in executive roles reflects an amicable, orderly and strategic approach to succession planning and execution by the Board. With RhythmOne's end to end programmatic platform now firmly in place, the window of opportunity to accelerate inorganic growth has provided the catalyst to leverage Ted's extensive M&A experience to accelerate the Company's growth and scale aspirations.
